author: AbcNews
title: Everything We Know About 'Potentially Catastrophic' Hurricane Patricia | International
text:
Hurricane Patricia is quickly moving toward the west coast of Mexico and is now the strongest hurricane ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere.
The category 5 storm, with sustained winds of 200 mph, could cause severe damage to coastal resort areas like Puerto Vallarta.
Here is what ABC News knows about the potentially devastating storm.
Forecasters expect Hurricane Patricia to hit the Pacific coast of Mexico before moving inland.
Where is it headed? The hurricane is expected to make landfall late this afternoon or early this evening near Manzanillo, a port city on Mexico's west coast.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration warns that it is "headed for potentially catastrophic landfall" and it could impact at least four Mexican states: Michoacan, Colima, Jalisco and Nayarit.
Forecasters expect Hurricane Patricia to hit the Pacific coast of Mexico before moving inland.
 How strong is it? Hurricane Patricia has sustained winds of 200 mph and central pressure of 880 mb, according to National Hurricane Center Spokesman Dennis Feltgen.
The Associated Press, citing the U.N.'s World Meteorological Organization, says Hurricane Patricia is comparable to Typhoon Haiyan, which left more than 7,300 people dead or missing when that storm hit the Philippines in 2013.
Mexico Braces for 'Potentially Catastrophic' Hurricane Patricia
What are some of the biggest concerns? The hurricane is expected to bring accumulated rains ranging from 6 to 12 inches which could easily produce "life-threatening flash floods, mud slides (especially in areas of mountainous terrain), and high winds up to 130 m.p.h.," NOAA warns.
The proximity to the coast is also cause for concern since any storm surges could lead to coastal flooding.
"Large and destructive waves" can be expected, and swells could cause deadly surf conditions and dangerous rip currents, NOAA reports.
Residents of Boca de Pascuales community are evacuated by local authorities before the arrival of hurricane Patricia in Colima State, Mexico, Oct. 22, 2015.more +
How can towns and local residents prepare? The U.S. embassy in Mexico City has issued a warning to all Americans in the hurricane's path.
"If you are in the hurricane warning area, you should make preparations immediately to protect life and property," the embassy's statement reads.
Schools in the state of Colima have been closed and various areas have declared states of emergencies, according to the AP.
Puerto Vallarta, a well-known resort town popular with foreigners, issued evacuations today and many tourists are being sent to one of 14 shelters in the state, the AP says.
